I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Strengthening  the  financial  sector  by  helping  to  develop  financial  institutions, 
infrastructure, and products and services is a key component of Strategy 2020.1 Through such 
initiatives,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  can  support  inclusive  economic  growth, 
stimulated by private sector investment, which can be a key contributing factor in reducing 
poverty. Technical assistance (TA) is an important value addition that ADB can provide to 
leverage  its  nonsovereign  funding,  and  is  a  development  tool  that  is  used  frequently  and 
successfully by bilateral and multilateral development banks in combination with private sector 
lending.2 For the financial sector, for instance, TA can be used to help financial institutions 
develop or test new products that they would normally not undertake, which can widen access 
to finance for underserved customer segments. TA can also be used to encourage financial 
institutions to improve corporate governance or anti-money laundering (AML) standards beyond 
local requirements. 
 
2.  As part of ADB’s efforts to strengthen the financial sector and enhance its development 
impact in its developing member countries (DMCs),  ADB has approved three regional capacity 
development TA projects for private sector financial institutions. The first project was completed 
in 2011 and the second project will be completed at the end of 2014. The third TA targets 
transition countries in Central Asia and Mongolia.3 These TA projects have been used along 
with ADB funding or guarantees to private sector financial institutions to enhance capacity 
development  for  (i)  corporate  governance  and  internal  controls;  (ii)  financing  strategies, 
including new product development; (iii) AML, antiterrorism, and anticorruption efforts; (iv) risk 
management;  and  (v)  environmental  and  social  safeguards.  Based  upon  the  successful 
utilization of the previous TA projects as well as the continued need for financial sector capacity 
development, the proposed TA for SEAP will continue to support financial sector development in 
these DMCs and enhance ADB’s development impact. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  A  strong  financial  sector  is  necessary  to  facilitate  economic  growth  and  financial 
inclusion,  which  underpins  poverty  reduction. 4  Financial  sector  development  is  varied 
throughout ADB’s DMCs in SEAP, and access to finance remains a major obstacle to private 
sector development and poverty alleviation. Domestic credit provided by the banking sector as a 
percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) has remained low in SEAP countries, indicating 
shallow financial intermediation. As of the end of 2013, domestic credit to the private sector as a 
percentage of GDP was 45.3% in Cambodia, 37.9% in Indonesia, 35.8% in the Philippines,  
68.1% in Vanuatu, and 77.9% in Fiji. This percentage was higher in neighboring countries such 
as Malaysia (124.3%) and Thailand (154.4%).5 In many SEAP countries, banking sector assets

have grown more slowly than GDP.6 Moreover, access to credit for small and medium-sized 
enterprises  (SMEs)  and  other  nontraditional  sector  borrowers  are  low  versus  larger,  more 
established borrowers.7 SME loans make up just 25% of total bank lending across Asia and the 
Pacific due to perceived risks associated with SMEs, projects’ bankability, and the lack of 
appropriate risk-based measures in place.8 The nonbanking sector in the SEAP region also 
remains undeveloped, with an average ratio of financial sector assets to GDP of 3%.9 This lack 
of development is exemplified by the fact that emerging Asian economies pay 3.0% of GDP to 
insurance premiums, while advanced Asian economies pay 11.8%.10  
 
4.  Access to finance is constrained due to a variety of reasons, including bank lending 
biases that favor upper-income borrowers, undiversified and short-term product offerings, and 
heavy data and large collateral requirements. Part of the solution to creating stronger and more 
diversified financial sectors in ADB’s DMCs is knowledge transfer and capacity building within 
banks to help them develop more innovative strategies and products tailored to a broader 
spectrum  of  borrowers,  including  SMEs.  In  addition,  corporate  governance,  AML,  and 
anticorruption efforts need to be strengthened in many financial institutions throughout the 
SEAP region. Related party transactions, for instance, are prevalent in Asia and need to be 
carefully monitored.11 Risk management practices are still below international standards, and 
with the move to Basel III and as financial systems in SEAP become larger, more complex, and 
more interconnected, many banks will need capacity development to ensure that adequate risk 
management systems are in place. Good environmental and social management systems and 
policies are also needed, and their introduction will typically require external expertise. 
 
5.  The following observations reflect SEAP country issues: 
(i)  Cambodia. The country has made progress in developing its financial sector 
since 2004. It has passed laws to support a market-driven system, strengthened 
key financial institutions, and emphasized the importance of supporting financial 
inclusion for the rural poor. However, financial infrastructure is still basic and 
assets are concentrated in a few large banks.12 Capacity development is needed 
to help reduce the skills gap and human capital deficits in the sector. Also, the 
nonbanking sector needs support with respect to the introduction of new products 
such as pension, leasing, and insurance. 
(ii)  Viet Nam. The country has expanded its financial sector significantly since 1991 
when the country had just 10 banks. In 2013, domestic credit provided by the 
private sector amounted to 96.8% of GDP (footnote 4). Viet Nam has more than 
97  banks,  evidence  of  an  increasingly  crowded  financial  system  structure 
according to the International Monetary Fund.13 The country’s financial sector is 
dominated, however, by five large state-owned banks representing approximately 
half of total assets and market share. The sector has low capital adequacy and 
high gross nonperforming loans by International Financial Reporting Standards

management. Moreover, given the number of unsustainable business models 
prevalent in the system, banks as well as institutions from the rising nonbank 
sector need to improve governance by creating proper incentives and improving 
operational  efficiency.  Meanwhile,  greater  emphasis  is  needed  on  financial 
inclusion. The main institutions providing microfinance services in Viet Nam are 
the state-owned banks and community-based cooperatives. Given the growth of 
the economy and the financial sector, reform and innovation is needed to meet 
the demand from the under-banked segment.  
(iii)  Myanmar. This country presents a special case in the region-having closed its 
doors to foreign investors in 1960. As the country opens, its rudimentary banking 
system  will  need  broad-scale  capacity  development  to  meet  the  projected 
demands of its growing economy.15  Today, the economy is still largely cash-
based, and only a few banks have recently introduced automated teller machines. 
Banks are only starting to establish wire transfer systems and relationships with 
correspondent banks. Confidence in the banking sector is quite low. Capacity 
development is thus needed on multiple levels. 
(iv)  Pacific developing member countries. Banks in the Pacific DMCs also have 
varied development needs. In 2013, Papua New Guinea’s ratio of domestic credit 
provided by the private sector to GDP was 34.9% and Timor-Leste’s was 11.3% 
(footnote 4). Multilateral development banks have worked to improve supervisory 
functions of the banking sector in Pacific DMCs by defining legal structures and 
implementing appropriate regulatory frameworks. Given the geography of the 
islands,  an  emphasis  is  being  placed  on  the  development  of  innovative 
branchless banking solutions and the ability to create more suitable banking 
products and processes (e.g., the ability for borrowers to pledge movable assets 
as collateral for loans).16 Further initiatives are needed to improve access to 
financial services by working with banks and nonbank lenders to reduce the high 
transaction costs associated with providing banking to dispersed populations, 
and building more financial services around insurance.17 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
6.  Selection criteria.  ADB will identify and select the qualified financial institutions (QFIs) 
based on the following criteria:   
(i)  The QFI should be a regulated financial institution (either private or public without 
a government guarantee) and the target of an ADB nonsovereign investment. 
(ii)  The QFI’s top management should be committed to pursuing innovative business 
practices and strengthening business operations. 
(iii)  The QFI’s management will put into place a project team to oversee the TA and 
agrees to share up to 50% of the TA cost.18

(iv)  The  QFI  has  or  is  willing  to  put  in  place  policies  complying  with  ADB’s 
governance  standards;  AML,  anticorruption,  and  antiterrorism  policies;  and 
environmental and social safeguards. 
(v)  ADB is satisfied with the integrity due diligence carried out on the QFI.   
(vi)  The Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) must be providing financial 
support or plans to provide financial support to the QFIs receiving the TA. 
 
7.  Country selection. The TA will cover financial institutions in all countries in SEAP. 
Given the variations in the financial sector across ADB’s DMCs in SEAP, needs assessments 
will  be  based  on  PSOD’s  evaluations,  country  partnership  strategies,  private  sector 
assessments, and third-party research.19  
  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact will be the enhanced capacity of selected financial institutions in the following 
areas:  (i)  corporate  governance;  know-your-client  policies;  and  AML,  antiterrorism, 
counterterrorist financing, and anticorruption efforts; (ii) financing strategy, including product 
development  with  respect  to  onlending  to  microfinance  borrowers,  SMEs,  housing, 
infrastructure, education and renewable energy, insurance, and leasing; (iii) risk management; 
and  (iv)  environmental  and  social  safeguards  policies  and  practices.  The  outcome  will  be 
strengthened policies and procedures to ensure improved corporate governance and extended 
reach into the microfinance, SME, housing, mobile banking, infrastructure, education, leasing, 
and/or insurance markets. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The methodology and key activities of the TA are dependent upon the capacity needs of 
the QFIs as evaluated by PSOD during the due diligence for the ADB funding or guarantees. 
Given the tailored nature of the TA, not all of the key activities noted below will be undertaken. 
Likely activities include the following:  
(i)  improving corporate governance and internal controls;  
(ii)  strengthening AML, anticorruption policies and antiterrorism policies; 
(iii)  developing    and  strengthening  innovative  financing  strategies,  including  new 
product development;  
(iv)  improving risk management; and  
(v)  maintaining or introducing an environmental and social management system. 
 
10.  The outputs will be accomplished through training and capacity building. Appendix 3 
provides the outline terms of reference for consultants. 
 
11.  The TA will also support regional seminars to share experiences and results, and solicit 
feedback for possible future interventions. Training programs will be held throughout the region

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, of which (i) $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and (ii) $450,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by QFIs and administered by ADB.20Details are provided in the 
 
cost estimates and financing plan (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be executed and implemented by ADB, with PSOD as the focal point.21 ADB, 
through PSOD, will be responsible for all technical implementation issues. Disbursements under 
the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over 36 months from the 
start date, coinciding with the approval date of the TA, and will adhere to the following: 
(i)  In accordance with Article 14(iii) of the ADB Charter, any activity under the TA 
will begin only after receiving a no-objection letter from the government of the 
country in which the QFI is located.22  
(ii)  The TA activities will be implemented with the help of international and national 
consultants and consultancy firms. Details are provided in the outline terms of 
reference for consultants (Appendix 3). 
(iii)  ADB  and  each  TA  recipient  will  form  a  project  planning  and  coordination 
committee  comprising  representatives  drawn from  appropriate  levels  of  each 
financial institution and ADB. Participating financial institutions will be selected in 
accordance with criteria recommended by the consultants and agreed by PSOD, 
broadly based on the each institution’s business line, historic project pipeline and 
portfolio, and commitment to participate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by qualified financial institutions, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for Promoting Capacity Building in 
Financial Institutions in Emerging Countries in Southeast Asia and the Pacific and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3                              
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.        Corporate Governance and Internal Controls 
 
1.  International firms with significant experience in corporate governance will be recruited 
to ensure that proper internal oversight structures are in place.1 Each engagement will require 
approximately two international consultants intermittently for 2 to 6 person-months, depending 
on the extent of the work needed for the given financial institution. Up to three engagements for 
this module are estimated. For each engagement, the firm will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Support the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in reviewing the existing corporate 
governance structure. 
(ii)  Assist  the  financial  institution  in  identifying  key  gaps  between  the  existing 
corporate governance framework and international best practice standards with 
regard to (a) the application of good corporate governance standards; (b) roles 
and responsibilities with regard to risk management of the supervisory body, 
directors, management board, and management support functions; (c) internal 
audit; (d) legal compliance; and (e) regulatory compliance. 
(iii)  Based on points (i) and (ii) above, assist the financial institution in preparing an 
action plan for strengthening corporate governance at various levels, including 
supervisory body, management board, management support functions, and post-
merger integration.2   
 
B.        Anti-Money Laundering, Antiterrorism, and Anticorruption Efforts  
 
2.  International firms with relevant experience and qualifications will be recruited for this 
module.3 One international firm will be selected for each engagement with an institution using 
consultant qualification selection in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, 
as amended from time to time). Each engagement will require approximately two international 
consultants intermittently for approximately 2 person-months. Up to two engagements for this 
module are estimated.  
 
3.  For each engagement, the firm will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Advise the institution and ADB on internationally accepted best practices for anti-
money laundering, antiterrorism, and anticorruption efforts in commercial banks.  
(ii)  Assess  the  current  anti-money  laundering,  antiterrorism,  and  anticorruption 
policies and procedures. Evaluate which areas in the policies and procedures are 
acceptable and follow best practices in their current form. If the policies and 
procedures  do  not  follow  best  practices,  make  initial  recommendations  on 
reorienting those areas to ensure best practices are in place. 
(iii)  Based on the points (i) and (ii), and in light of best practices, prepare a report on 
observations and recommendations. The report should include recommendations

3 Consultants should have professional qualifications in anti-money laundering. Qualifications and experience may

Appendix 3  11 
 
on  amending  or  changing  the  anti-money  laundering,  antiterrorism,  and 
anticorruption policies and procedures. 
(iv)  Provide advice, contacts, and coordination support for the international training 
component, and coordinate support as needed. 
  
C.        Financing Strategies 
 
4.  Up to three individual international consultants will be selected for this module.4 Up to 
two  consultants  will  be  selected  for  each  engagement  with  a  given  institution,  and  each 
engagement will require approximately 2 to 6 person-months intermittently. 
 
5.  For each engagement, the consultants will 
(i)  review existing microfinance, small and medium-sized enterprise (SME), housing, 
infrastructure, clean energy, mobile banking, leasing, and/or insurance products;  
(ii)  review financing and product needs of the customer base and assess other 
potential customer segments;  
(iii)  provide international benchmarks for microfinance, SMEs, housing, infrastructure, 
clean energy, mobile banking, leasing, and/or insurance products, and assess 
relevant products, risk mitigation measures and concerns; 
(iv)  develop a microfinance, SME, housing, education, infrastructure, clean energy, 
mobile banking, leasing, and/or insurance product strategy;  
(v)  assist in the design of financing products; and 
(vi)  examine  ways  to  optimize  financial  institutions’  balance  sheets  to  achieve 
sustainable  growth  in  terms  of  capital  structure  and  asset  and  liability 
management. 
 
D.        Risk Management 
 
6.  International  firms  that  have  high-level  qualifications  and  significant  experience  in 
evaluating operations risk management and internal controls will be recruited to ensure that the 
proper internal oversight structures are in place (footnote 4). One international firm will be 
selected for each engagement with a given financial institution using consultant qualification 
selection in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The firm will have 
prior experience on similar projects with financial institutions in the country where the technical 
assistance is being employed. Each engagement will require approximately two international 
consultants intermittently for 2 to 6 person-months, depending on the extent of the work needed 
for the given financial institution. Up to three engagements for this module are estimated.  
 
7.  For each engagement, the firm will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Advise  the  financial  institution  and  ADB  about  internationally  accepted  best 
practices for risk management in commercial banks. 
(ii)  Support  ADB  in  reviewing  the  institution’s  policies  and  procedures  on  risk 
management and internal control. These will include the draft operations risk 
management  framework  prepared  by  the  institution,  as  well  as  other  credit 
policies and the critical components and methodology. Evaluate which areas in 
the operations risk management framework and policies, in their current form, 
are acceptable and follow best practices. If the operations risk management 
                                                
4  International consultants should have university degrees in economics and finance as well as banking experience. 
Qualifications and experience may change depending on the actual needs of the respective financial institution.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
framework  and  policies  do  not  follow  best  practices,  make  initial 
recommendations on reorienting those areas in the framework to ensure best 
practices are in place. 
(iii)  Assess  the  internal  controls  outlined  in  the  operations  risk  management 
framework and determine whether they are sufficient and properly integrated into 
the framework. 
(iv)  Examine  the  organizational  structure  of  the  various  departments  and  risk 
management  groups  or  committees,  particularly  the  extent  of  separation  of 
managerial  roles  and  responsibilities.  Assess  whether  there  are  sufficient 
safeguards to ensure adequate internal controls and oversight. 
(v)  Based on points (i) to (iv), and in light of best practices, prepare a report that 
includes  recommendations  on  amending  or  changing  the  operations  risk 
management framework, including key definitions and streamlining of the current 
system. 
(vi)  Provide advice, contacts, and coordination support for the international training 
component (if necessary). 
 
E.  Environmental and Social Safeguards Consultant 
 
8.  Six to eight individual national consultants will be selected for this module in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.5 Up to two consultants will be selected for 
each engagement with a given institution, for approximately 1 person-month each. Up to three 
engagements for this module are estimated.  
 
9.  For each engagement, the consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  advise the institution on internationally accepted best practices for environmental 
awareness and safeguards in commercial banks;  
(ii)  provide  advice,  contacts,  and  coordinating  support,  as  needed,  for  the 
international training component; and 
(iii)  assist in drafting an environmental and social management system in compliance 
with ADB’s environmental and social safeguards policies. 
 
10.  Additionally, a 1-day training seminar will be held for approximately 20–25 participants, 
who will be credit officers with underwriting responsibility in the financial institution’s credit 
review process. Participants must be in managerial positions so that they have the possibility of 
disseminating the seminar content to other financial institution staff. The suggested seminar 
outline will include: 
 (i)  Session 1: Environmental and social issues in the institution’s transactions 
(about 1 hour). The presentation will aim to answer why the institution needs to 
consider  environmental  and  social  aspects  in  its  business.  It  will  cover 
environmental and social risks and opportunities in the institution’s transactions, 
with examples of environmental and social risks.6 
(ii)  Session 2: Laws, regulations, and standards on environmental assessment 
(about  3  hours).  The  speakers  will  give  an  overview  of  specific  national 
environmental regulations and their implications for the institution’s business. 
These include

  ADB 2013. Procurement Guidelines. Manila. 
6 including involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples

Appendix 3  13 
 
(a)  risks for  and  obligations  of  lenders  under  national  environmental  and 
other regulations and laws with respect to environmental issues; 
(b)  national  requirements  for  environmental  assessment  of  greenfield 
projects and refinancing of existing projects;  
(c)  requirements  for  environmental  assessment  and  implications  for      
corporate lending;  
(d)  environmental  risks  and  their  assessment  in  other  banking  areas, 
e.g., retail, asset management, capital markets, and advisory; and 
(e)  implications for the institution’s business. 
 (iii)  Session 3: ADB’s approach to environmental assessment (about 1 hour). 
The speaker will cover ADB’s environmental requirements as applied to ADB-
financed  projects,  compare  ADB’s  standards  to  those  of  other  financial 
institutions and the Equator Principles, and reference them to national policies.7  
 (iv)  Session 4: Concepts and principles of environmental management and an 
environmental management system, as well as environmental management 
practices in selected financial institutions (2 hours). The presentation will 
(a) cover  the  concepts  and  principles  of  environmental  management  and  an 
environmental  management  system  in  financial  institutions,  and  (b)  provide 
examples and case studies of such systems and practices in selected financial 
institutions. The presentation will show clearly how an environment management 
system should work in a financial institution while referencing this to the particular 
institution’s own regulatory and business environment, as well as to the context 
of its businesses (e.g., retail, corporate). 
 (v)  Session 5: Next steps (1.5 hours). The speaker will present ideas on the next 
steps  that  the  institution  should  take  toward  institutionalizing  environmental 
management in its organization. This session will be used as an open forum for 
the participants to give their views and suggestions regarding those next steps. 
 
11.  The training seminar will be evaluated as follows: 
(i)  Measures of efficiency, including: 
(a)  performance of the speakers (observations and participants’ evaluations), 
(b)  participation of the participants in the open discussion (observation), 
(c)  percentage of participants attending all sessions (records), 
(d)  satisfaction of the participants (participants’ evaluations), and 
(e)  punctuality of the presentation and participants (observation and records). 
(ii)  Measures  of  outcome  or  effectiveness,  including:  (a)  method—a  structured 
questionnaire  and  interviews  with  randomly  selected  participants;  (b) 
benchmark—knowledge and understanding of participants on the subject before 
the seminar, which should assessed prior to the seminar using a well-structured 
questionnaire; and (c) seminar rating. 
 
F.  Training Conferences for Qualified Financial Institutions   
 
12.  ADB may also require training seminars to be conducted, which will focus on key areas 
of the modules noted in paras. 1–9. The contents of the seminar will be tailored to the needs of 
the banks in these respective countries and the TA work that other development banks are 
                                                
7 The Equator Principles is a risk management framework adopted by financial institutions for determining, assessing 
and managing environmental and social risk in projects and is primarily intended to provide a minimum standard for 
due diligence to support responsible risk decision-making.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
undertaking. Given the length of the seminar, the topics addressed will be introductory and 
geared to the prevailing level of financial sector development. 
 
G.  Reporting Arrangements 
 
13.  The  consultant  firm  will  be  responsible  for  preparing,  as  required  (i)  brief  monthly 
progress reports with updates on implementation until the project is completed, and (ii) a draft 
final report 2 weeks before completion of the tasks under the respective TA component. The 
draft final report will be revised and resubmitted after receiving comments from ADB and the 
institution.
